meanings.sent1: After the game, they decided to reargue about who scored the winning goal.
meanings.sent2: Lawyers often reargue their cases in court to try to convince the judge.
meanings.sent3: The siblings would reargue over who got the bigger slice of cake, always ending in laughter.
meanings.sent4: The students continued to reargue their points like a never-ending debate.
meanings.sent5: The teacher asked the students to reargue their opinions with more evidence.

meanings.definition: To present arguments again in support of (a claim or position)
meanings.sent1: She had to reargue her case to the committee to get their approval.
meanings.sent2: The politician decided to reargue his stance on the controversial issue.
meanings.sent3: The lawyer had to reargue her client's innocence after new evidence came to light.
meanings.sent4: The scientist reargued his theory with updated data to convince his peers.
meanings.sent5: The author had to reargue the importance of her book to the publisher.
